instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.820-2330: What is 820-2330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.ISL6258: What is ISL6258? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2008 through 2009.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
threads.message:
Hello,

I'm new to board repairs and I need your help. I have a MacBook Pro 17" 2009 with an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A motherboard that has a green light but it does not turn on. It does not have any signs of water damage, and besides of a few scuffs and dents it looks alright. The customer told me that it simply didn't want to start anymore, as I said no liquid or major signs of mechanic accidents.

When I took the board out and connected it to the charger I saw smoke coming out from <TRANSISTOR>Q4260</TRANSISTOR> so I have removed it. His father has a construction company and has a FLIR camera and with that I saw that <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> was the "hottest" chip from the motherboard, in fact when connected to charger was the only one hot or rather warm (40[COLOR=#545454][FONT=arial]Â°[/FONT][/COLOR]C).

I have a few measurements :

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.11V
<SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> - 17V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.41V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.4V

Still learning so I may write something dumb or ask stupid questions ... so please be patient.

Also I have another board (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) with the exact same problems (green light but does not turn on, no liquid damage) but I can't find the brd file to take some measurements, maybe you can help me with it.

Thanks !

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
threads.message: Check voltage on <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>, it should be 1.05V. If not then replace <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>, can be a bigger regular cap, just wire it in there. This is the same for both boards.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
threads.message: Plugged it in today and no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was 0,02V, ONEWIRE was very low also. Leaved it plugged, done a few phones and noticed it was green again without doing anything. <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>  is 0V, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> also 0V, ordered today some caps and will try to replace it tomorrow but something is fishy. I saw on Louis's video that he had 8.37V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, mine is 3-3.4V.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
threads.message: You have an issue around the <CHIP>ISL6258</CHIP> I think, check the sense resistor circuits.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>ISL6258</CHIP>, when connected to power <TRANSISTOR>Q4260</TRANSISTOR> (I have replaced it too) went into flames again :) I have 8.4V on G3H now and 1.10V on <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>, still it doesn't turn on.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q4260</TRANSISTOR> is only for FireWire so not important. Are you using a known good REAL 85W charger?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green Light but does not turn on
threads.message: That was it, I was using the the 65W. It booted :) This is my first board repaired, you can mark it as solved. Thanks ;)
